<tr id="pagespace" style="height:10px" title="Show HN: I got laid off from Meta and created a minor hit on Steam"></tr><tr><td><table border="0" class="fatitem">
<tr class="athing submission" id="43186406">
<td align="right" class="title" valign="top"><span class="rank"></span></td> <td class="votelinks" valign="top"><center><a href="vote?id=43186406&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43186406"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="title"><span class="titleline"><a href="item?id=43186406">Show HN: I got laid off from Meta and created a minor hit on Steam</a></span></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"></td><td class="subtext"><span class="subline">
<span class="score" id="score_43186406">735 points</span> by <a class="hnuser" href="user?id=newobj">newobj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T18:19:05 1740593945"><a href="item?id=43186406">9 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43186406"></span> | <a href="hide?id=43186406&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406">hide</a> | <a class="hnpast" href="https://hn.algolia.com/?query=Show%20HN%3A%20I%20got%20laid%20off%20from%20Meta%20and%20created%20a%20minor%20hit%20on%20Steam&amp;type=story&amp;dateRange=all&amp;sort=byDate&amp;storyText=false&amp;prefix&amp;page=0">past</a> | <a href="fave?id=43186406&amp;auth=4bab63e6286419054a94b4ec5e8886ff0e5afa2f">favorite</a> | <a href="item?id=43186406">191 comments</a> </span>
</td></tr>
<tr><td style="height:2px"></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"></td><td><div class="toptext">I was at FB/Meta from late 2013 to early 2023, mostly working in the compiler/runtime spaces. I got hit in the spring 2023 layoff wave. I immediately started making games in my newfound free time (a lifelong interest, and I even worked in AA(A?) back ca. ~2000), and in October 2023 I stumbled upon the idea of a roguelike pachinko/plinko game inspired by Luck Be A Landlord. Things snowballed quickly, I started talking to publishers, then worked like crazy through all of 2024, almost the hardest I've ever worked in my career, and launched the game in December 2024. It's sold ~200,000 units in its first 10 weeks on Steam. So it's no Balatro, but I'd still say it did very well :) AMA?<p>(my game is Ballionaire: <a href="https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2667120/view/526461473225965590" rel="nofollow">https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2667120/view/5264614...</a>)</p></div></td></tr> <tr><td style="height:10px"></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"></td><td><form action="comment" method="post"><input name="parent" type="hidden" value="43186406"/><input name="goto" type="hidden" value="item?id=43186406"/><input name="hmac" type="hidden" value="fd3e98bfc29d14c2ddc9bf355f2461d85a1e22d8"/><textarea cols="80" name="text" rows="8" wrap="virtual"></textarea><br/><br/>
<input type="submit" value="add comment"/></form></td></tr> </table><br/><br/><table border="0" class="comment-tree">
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190446"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190446&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190446"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=randfish">randfish</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T01:55:22 1740621322"><a href="item?id=43190446">4 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190446"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189043">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190446" n="7">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Incredible work, Brian! I'm in awe of what you've done in such a short amount of time. I started an indie game company (still working on our first title) and had a few related questions if that's OK?<p>1) If you didn't need a salary or marketing help, would you still have signed a publishing deal? My sense is most of the publisher value lies in getting paid before the game launches, and with marketing around launch, but curious if those are wrong assumptions?<p>2) Early Access vs. Straight Launch - any insights about why you chose to do a full launch vs. an early access beforehand? Was it something you and the publisher discussed in detail?<p>3) Outside of Steam's ecosystem, how much marketing, promotion, social media, YouTube, Discord, etc. stuff did you (or the publisher) do? Do you think that pre-launch work had a sizable impact on the launch and post-launch success? Or would you say it's mostly the Steam algo making the game more visible to the right buyers as the positive reviews rolled in?<p>Truly kind of you to share so openly here. Already sent some of your other replies to our game team</p></p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190446&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343190446" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190567"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190567&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190567"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=newobj">newobj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T02:13:32 1740622412"><a href="item?id=43190567">4 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190567"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190446">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190491">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190567" n="4">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Thanks Rand!<p>1) It obviously varies w/ each dev's situation, but I think your sense of the value prop is a fair default one w/o context. In my case, there were four reasons: 1) having a partner to help with (to me) "the unknown unknowns" (i'm only a dev and a novice designer, literally anything else would be my first time doing it, so i figured having an experienced partner there would be wise) 2) the advance was nice just from a "bird in the hand" mindset 3) they helped me connect with a really good artist (critical to the project's success imho) 4) having a big name behind you can't hurt, and bigger publishers do have more relationships with the ecosystem (streamers, platforms, etc) to help your game succeed.<p>2) EA is appropriate for certain kinds of games. But I knew exactly what Ballionaire was going to be, and felt it could be achieved in a year. I knew that this mechanical space was going to be rapidly saturated, once all the games inspired by LBAL (including Balatro!) started appearing. So I was determined to get the game out before that happened, which set a certain scope and pace, obviating EA.<p>3) The trailers were a really good promotional tool, very effective. But most of the paid promotion was sponsored streams, not traditional "marketing" (ads). I think the game has a natural tendency for organic spread, due to its fun/simple premise, watchability/streamability, low price point, and so on. It's just an easy game to see, and say "ooh, I wanna try!" because it's instantly understood how to play, and IMHO is very inviting aesthetically.<p>My takeaway: Make sure your hook is glowingly radioactively good. Don't overbalance. Leave in some jank. Scope down and finish quickly. And avoid tropes. Stand out. (Of course this only works for a certain kind of game!)</p></p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190567&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343190567" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

<div class="commtext c00">How far were you into building the game before you began to approach publishers? YC speaks frequently about investing in the founders, and not the idea---but then dives right into well you need to have revenue and/or users and it's a bit of a double-standard---so I'm curious what stage you were at when you started talking to publishers and what state your product was in when you finally signed a deal.</div>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189043"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">

<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=switz">switz</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T22:34:15 1740609255"><a href="item?id=43189043">7 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189043"></span> <span class="navs">

</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">200,000 units is a far cry from just a 'minor hit' - congratulations!<p>During the project, what was the biggest instinct you had that was ultimately validated by its success, but still surprised you? What was a lesson you learned that you didn't expect? How was working with a publisher? What did they do right and what did they do wrong?</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189043&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189043" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189518"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189518&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189518"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=newobj">newobj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T23:31:16 1740612676"><a href="item?id=43189518">6 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189518"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189043">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190274">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189518" n="7">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Honest answer? Dancing stick figure guy on the title screen. I did it very early in the project, in a fugue state at 3am. It lingered and lingered there, with ppl wondering "Is this real? Is this the actual title screen?" and luckily by the end I think everyone had drank enough psychedelic koolaid to agree - stick figure man stays. The artist made some better art for his hands/feet, and that was that. He's divisive, but everybody at least remembers him :)<p>Lesson learned that I didn't expect - hmm. Ah, one good one: I spent a <i>LOT</i> of time worrying about stuff being "OP" or degenerately good. Well, turns out, people like OP stuff, or degenerately good stuff, at least in single player score attack games. My biggest lesson learned on the project: people experience your game individually. If they find something broken, in their head, <i>they</i> are the one to have found something broken, and it feels good. You don't have to design for the entire community at once. Don't over-balance your game. Embrace the jank.</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189518&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189518" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189819"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="2"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="80"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189819&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189819"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">

Was anyone upset or disappointed you were working on a game and not getting another job at a big tech company?<p>I don’t mean to be critical, but I’ve always faced pushback working on startups/side projects, and I’m wondering how that was for you?</p></div>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190452"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190452&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190452"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=newobj">newobj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T01:55:53 1740621353"><a href="item?id=43190452">4 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190452"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190358">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190587">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190452" n="7">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">It was discussed with my family (wife/kid) that this was going to be my near singular focus for a year, and it basically was. Luckily everyone was supportive because they knew how long I'd wanted to do this, and the fact that I already had a "good idea" with some proof on my hands certainly made it easier. Having traction helped convinced everyone, myself included, that it would be a worthwhile investment of time, and not just "fucking around in the basement." No one was disappointed that I was not getting another big tech job. I'd just spent 20 years in FAANG.</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190452&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343190452" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>

<div class="commtext c00">I think people doing gamedev who have/had a day job writing business software have a tendency to eschew all the boring scope/time management/actually shipping stuff because being able to just write the code you want and spend however long you want polishing it is so freeing.<p>Seeing someone come from the corporate world to gamedev and seemingly carry over all the right lessons and keep the discipline is pretty awesome, kudos.</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">

<div class="commtext c00">I mean video games are notoriously competitive, and very little money comes in until it launches after a year of building. It was not impossible OP was going to launch to 4000 customers.<p>I think OP’s story is inspiring, and I’m happy to hear he had support, but I could also see a wife being upset her previously highly paid husband is working on a video game, and presumably a low salary from a publisher (if any).<p>When I was working on my previous startup we had a couple customers and a small investment, but I got intense pushback from a female friend who would often come and live with me. She couldn’t stand the fact I was passing on a high salary to work on something I cared about, and we weren’t even dating. The 1.5 years+ she referred to me as unemployed lol<p>Again though I don’t mean to be critical of OP or his dream, I was just curious about the social dynamic he encountered.</p></p></p></div>

<div class="commtext c00">&gt;It was not impossible OP was going to launch to 4000 customers.<p>Having a publisher helps a lot. But 4000 copies for many indies would be a rousing success (albeit, not a financial success). It is simply that competitive.<p>&gt;I could also see a wife being upset her previously highly paid husband is working on a video game, and presumably a low salary from a publisher (if any).<p>Very true for 99.99% of indie devs. But I figure that OP's savings and RSU's (almost a deacade's worth) would easily put them in a situation everyone else can only dream of.<p>&gt;When I was working on my previous startup...<p>I know startups are risky, but I really don't get this attitude. It might just be lack of knowledge, but once you can get a startup off its feet, the VC money from seeds easily makes up for that downtime. And unless you're the founder or are a near-founder being paid with future equity, startups can still pay very respectably. It's the time committment that you need to worry about.</p></p></p></p></p></div>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190126"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190126&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190126"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=RheingoldRiver">RheingoldRiver</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T00:50:25 1740617425"><a href="item?id=43190126">5 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190126"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190358">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43187385">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190126" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">We had someone request a wiki on wiki.gg for Ballionaire, and it's at <a href="https://ballionaire.wiki.gg/wiki/Ballionaire_Wiki" rel="nofollow">https://ballionaire.wiki.gg/wiki/Ballionaire_Wiki</a>. Assuming you have structured data easily accessible, you can pretty easily use the MediaWiki API to create some automated pages for each of the items and any other entities that should have pages. Example repo: <a href="https://github.com/RheingoldRiver/sorcerer-update">https://github.com/RheingoldRiver/sorcerer-update</a> That repo is assuming that some "infobox" templates already exist, which you can find documentation about here: <a href="https://support.wiki.gg/wiki/DRUID_infoboxes" rel="nofollow">https://support.wiki.gg/wiki/DRUID_infoboxes</a> or feel free to email me (address in bio) if you'd want to create the pages assuming that the infobox template already exists and have me make said template for you!</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190126&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343190126" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43187385"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43187385&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43187385"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=billconan">billconan</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T19:47:05 1740599225"><a href="item?id=43187385">8 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43187385"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190126">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189208">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43187385" n="8">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Congratulations! The game looks amazing—its quality is truly impressive.<p>I'm currently feeling burned out. I have an app idea and a prototype that I believe could turn into a viable project to support myself. However, I don't have the courage to quit my job—I’m afraid of the anxiety that comes with paying rent and insurance without a steady paycheck. I do have some savings to sustain me for a while, but I'm unsure if taking a break to recharge, learn new things, and build something I'm passionate about (which could potentially become profitable) is a good idea? I'm also worried about how a long gap on my resume might be perceived when I look for a job in the future.<p>I'm also interested in making video games, but I often get discouraged by the sheer amount of artwork required—something I struggle to handle and afford. How did you manage the artwork side of your project?</p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43187385&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343187385" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43187385">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189049">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43188849" n="2">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Thanks Bill :)<p>I can relate to the first thing you mentioned, and I never really took action. Layoff was thrust upon me, with the privilege of a severance, and I had been working for decades, so I figured "why not try now?" I'm not sure if I ever would have been brave enough to proactively try, but that's just me. Video games in particular are brutal, economically, and not something I would ever recommend someone take a risk on in hopes of a payday.<p>Regarding art: don't get distracted by art. The original prototype of Ballionaire was made using Twemoji -- you can see a video of it here: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CwIwcGewZME" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CwIwcGewZME</a> Later I switched from Twemoji to images sourced from <a href="https://www.flaticon.com/" rel="nofollow">https://www.flaticon.com/</a> When I signed a publisher, I was lucky enough for them to hook me up with an in-house artist. I knew the style I wanted (the style you see in the game) and luckily the artist Hanja absolutely nailed it.<p>I would recommend avoiding art as long as possible if it's not your strength. You will go much further on making something <i>feel</i> really <i>fun</i> then making art that's one click above terrible. If you get traction, the art can come later. For future prototypes I am working on straight up text mode (or near to it, in like stock Godot UI) right now.</p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43188849&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343188849" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189321"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">

             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43187385">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189049">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189208">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189321" n="3">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>

<div class="commtext c00">Have you considered switching careers rather than quiting. I took a two year break from tech and did English teaching. The pay was low but it sustained me with my savings and I had tons of mental energy to work on my side projects. Any job that's easy to clock in and clock out, where the work gets done on the same day, no deadlines. Can do wonders for your mental energy.<p>When I returned to tech I had a pretty impressive portfolio of projects. Turns out unsurprisingly that not coding all day for work makes me want to code more for fun.</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189321&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189321" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

There are a lot of jobs out there that are easy to learn and adapt to.<p>Before teaching I did a cleaning job which was satisfying. Headphones in and end my day with the satisfaction of a clean office for the workers tomorrow. City gardening jobs were also lovely. Being out in the sun does wonders for mood. Impossible to get stressed doing the job.<p>But yeah, it's always scary that bad management can ruin a good thing.</p></p></div>

<div class="commtext c00">Out of curiosity, what kind of margins do you get when you sell a game on Steam? Like, what percentage of a sale ends up in your bank account (pre-taxes).  Also, how do Steam sales affect that?<p>Congrats on making a game to completion, and doubly so for making something that gets fairly popular.  Making a real game has been on my bucket list for about as long as I've known how to program, and I haven't completely given up on it, but I would need to make friends with someone who knows how to do art and music.</p></div>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189295"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189295&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189295"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=newobj">newobj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T23:02:54 1740610974"><a href="item?id=43189295">7 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189295"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189208">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189263">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189295" n="5">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Between returns, taxes, and other stuff, I think you can model at ~55% of gross Steam sales. Then, whatever your split w/ your publisher is, on top of that. So I think it's easy for ppl to severely overestimate how much a dev is actually earning by just multiplying units times price :)<p>I think in general the uptick of sales volume more than offsets the discount during a Steam sale. There's a reason Steam sales have a cooldown, they generate marketing emails to your wishlists. So sales are always good, from what I can tell.<p>Thanks for the congrats, and all I can say is: don't give up, I'm an old-ass man and made it happen. Don't get stuck on art or music either, IMHO. Total distraction. You can make a game fun without that stuff. At least, fun enough to be sure the investment into the next stage is wise.</p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189295&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189295" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189502"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="3"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="120"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189502&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189502"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=zamalek">zamalek</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T23:29:53 1740612593"><a href="item?id=43189502">6 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189502"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189208">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189345">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189263">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189502" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">One major benefit of publishers is a salary while the game is being developed. The other major benefit is marketing, the linked Steam page is titled:<p>&gt; 200K Ballionaires!<p>&gt; Where do you all keep coming from?!<p>A good portion of those came from the publisher's efforts.</p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189263"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189263&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189263"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=echoangle">echoangle</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T22:59:00 1740610740"><a href="item?id=43189263">7 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189263"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189208">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189295">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189264">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189263" n="7">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Steam takes 30% and the publisher ( <a href="https://rawfury.com/developer-resources/" rel="nofollow">https://rawfury.com/developer-resources/</a> ) takes 50%, so the dev should end up with 35% of revenue (which then needs to be taxed etc.).</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189263&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189263" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189383"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="3"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="120"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">

</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Depends on the deal. Promotion and fronting of cash are the big ones (usually). They can usually also offer various development services (testing, translation, porting, getting special deals with platform holders). They can also act as a stakeholder for quality, advising on certain things that should be improved (as an editor would in book publishing).</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189383&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189383" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

<div class="commtext c00">If you look on the Steam page it's Raw Fury.<p>Steam is just the storefront. A game publisher's role varies a lot - sometimes they're just financing the project, usually they handle stuff like PR and marketing, and sometimes they help quite a bit more with the development of the game (sounds like the case in this case based on his other answers) as in programming/art/sfx/whatever else.</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189380&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189380" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190641"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="3"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="120"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190641&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190641"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=devsda">devsda</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T02:22:58 1740622978"><a href="item?id=43190641">4 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190641"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189109">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190410">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190109">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190641" n="2">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">&gt; Large companies definitely don’t try to prohibit you from telling people you worked there.<p>They don't. But they do sometimes prohibit talking/writing about their work, the nature of it or anything remotely connected to it.<p>My current employer explicitly  prohibits us from blogging about technical topics, creating learning material or even teaching anyone on technical subjects(e.g. on weekends at nearby school) outside the job for free/money.</p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190641&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343190641" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190861"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="4"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="160"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190861&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190861"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=sarchertech">sarchertech</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T02:59:59 1740625199"><a href="item?id=43190861">3 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190861"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189109">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190641">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190109">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190861" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">That’s not very common either. I’ve never signed anything like that in 20 years in the industry (worked everywhere from tiny startups to very large tech companies).<p>In the case where your company does have a policy that that prohibits you from discussing the nature of your work, it’s likely completely unenforceable beyond them firing firing you.<p>The prohibition from teaching or blogging is definitely unenforceable.</p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43191572"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43191572&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43191572"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=Buttons840">Buttons840</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T05:15:28 1740633328"><a href="item?id=43191572">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43191572"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189109">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43191695">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43191572" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Do you think "diamond in the rough" games exist?<p>Some claim that there are games that are hidden gems that haven't received the recognition they deserve.<p>Other claim they have never seen a generally good game that didn't have generally good success.<p>What is your view?<p>I think some games are good within their niche, but their niche sucks. Something like a hardcore roguelike with ASCII graphics. Within the hardcore roguelike niche, the ASCII game might be "good" and have some interesting new mechanics, good execution, etc; but within the entire gaming industry, classic roguelikes with ASCII graphics are outdated, they "suck". Some will say the ASCII roguelike is underappreciated, but only because they over-appreciate the niche.<p>I'd like to believe that a generally good game guarantees at least some success.</p></p></p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43191572&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343191572" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<div class="commtext c00">Amazing work! Questions:<p>- How/why did you decide to talk to a publisher? When in the process did you feel like you had a good enough prototype to do that?<p>- What have been the pros/cons of working with a publisher? When, in your opinion, should someone do that vs. self-publishing?<p>- What was your confidence level throughout various stages of the project? Was there a point before releasing the game where you maybe got a glimpse of the success you were going to have? (I guess probably Steam wishlists?)<p>- What's next?<p>Congrats again on the hit!</p></p></p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189361&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189361" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189659"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189659&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189659"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=newobj">newobj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T23:48:56 1740613736"><a href="item?id=43189659">6 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189659"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189361">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43191785">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189659" n="2">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">I worked with a publisher for a few reasons: 1) I didn't know what I didn't know, and didn't want to "find out" AND make the game at the same time. I needed a partner for the business/marketing end. 2) An advance (funding) helped de-risk things for me. 3) I needed help to find an artist. I was having no luck on my own. Even with the traction the game had!<p>Publishers actually came to me. In a weird coincidence, I happened to show the game in a Discord where localthunk, the Balatro dev, was hanging out, and he shared it with a few big streamers. The prototype was streamed to thousands of people like ~5 weeks into its development, and the publishers started showing up immediately. Not normal. Very lucky.<p>I started very confident, and stayed relatively confident, for myself, but there were some weird days where you'd get a paranoid feeling: "Wait, all you do is drop a ball in this game. Why do people like it? Are they just blowing smoke up my ass? Am I having a manic break, thinking the gmae is good? It really can't possibly be good enough, right? Making successful indie games is something <i>other</i> people do, not me." Needless to say the demo getting reception in October 2024 Steam Nextfest (before being released in December) was hugely validating and was like the "pinch" I needed to prove it wasn't a dream.<p>Next is healing and recovery ... and supporting Ballionaire. Working on a creative project intensely for a year at the exclusion of almost everything else in your life, esp. at my age -- doesn't leave you in a great state when it's over. It was self-imposed crunch mode. It's not easy to be bounce back creatively or energetically.<p>Thanks :)</p></p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189659&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189659" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43191043"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="2"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="80"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">

</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Appreciate your vulnerability. Awesome to hear your good fortune along the way, receiving positive feedback. Working a year heads-down even with that though does sound quite difficult. I think about all the time how one doesn't have to deal with these kinds of doubts when at FAANG-style jobs. I think <i>that</i>, moreso even than the EV on compensation, is the reason FAANG can be so sticky.</div>

<div class="commtext c00">Very cool!<p>- What choices did you make to give yourself more time to work on this project?<p>- At what point did you begin getting feedback of some sort?<p>- Were there clearly things you wished to include in the game but had to cut out in the interest of time? How did you decide what would be "good enough"?</p></p></p></div>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189723"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189723&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189723"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=newobj">newobj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T23:57:24 1740614244"><a href="item?id=43189723">6 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189723"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189201">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190347">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189723" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">I very explicitly, with my family's support, set up the expectation that the game was my #1 priority in 2024. I only took one small vacation, during which I still worked. My wife and I would watch one 30 minute tv show at night, and do the crossword in the morning, and other than that, aside from meal time, the expectation was that I would be working on the game by default (not that I worked non-stop, just that the default was "the game"). It was fully 7 days a week for like 30% of the project. Involuntarily, I sacrificed exercise and diet too :( I just couldn't manage the discipline. I also absolutely annihilated the quality of my sleep.<p>I got feedback from my wife within a few days, the first time she saw the game. Even she, a non-gamer, could tell that there was something compelling about the idea. And if you look at an above response, you'll see that I explained that the prototype, about a month into dev, go streamed to thousands of people. The feedback was VERY early and very positive. I wouldn't have been brave enough to keep at it otherwise, knowing myself.<p>I wish meta progression was better, what shipped was a compromise with respect to time. "Good enough" was just purely just vibes and an editorial eye. No articulable criteria. Just a lot of vibes and trusting my intuition (a skill I gained verrrrrrry late in life)</p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189723&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189723" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190011"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190011&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190011"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=newobj">newobj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T00:35:19 1740616519"><a href="item?id=43190011">5 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190011"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189760">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189313">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190011" n="2">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">FWIW, it works on the Steamdeck, natively, without Proton -- so it's a native Linux game in other words. Apparently a lot of folks are playing it on desktop Linux, as a result. It's just not "officially supported".<p>I'm a one-man dev operation, so it's strictly a matter of opportunity costs of my time. Linux and Mac are miniscule gaming markets, like 1% of Windows, but could potentially generate a significantly proportionately greater burden of support. So I have to be careful there.</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190011&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343190011" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<div class="commtext c00">I crunched myself to get the game out by the end of 2024 before the saturation I knew was coming took place. I think the simple premise, watchability, humor, and presentation of the game helped it stand out.<p>My advice: Have a super solid hook, that's marketing. Everything else is promotion and is far less effective.</p></div>

<div class="commtext c00">Thanks! Godot 4.2 w/ C#. I started with Godot 3 and C#, but ported to Godot 4 a couple months into the project, because it was my understanding that would help console portability in the future. It was a bit of a pain, but not too bad. Maybe a week's worth of work.<p>Raw Fury I think also did a great job w/ marketing and promotion, e.g. connecting the game to streamers, and the trailer knocked it out of the park IMHO :)</p></div>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189325"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189325&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189325"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=newobj">newobj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T23:07:57 1740611277"><a href="item?id=43189325">7 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189325"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189122">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189442">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189325" n="2">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Godot 4.2 / C#. Godot is an amazing engine and I highly recommend it for indie devs. The iteration cycle is a few seconds. IMHO, using Unity will absolutely slow you down, as a designer/programmer. I can't comment on the reality of a 3d game with a complicated art pipeline, however. But for a game like Ballionaire, Unity or Unreal would have been a mistake.<p>Ballionaire was fun by day 3, the first time a ball dropped and hit a trigger that caused an effect. It was luck a bolt of lightning to me. I am a VERY pessimistic person. So the fact that it felt compelling that early, and like, anyone who saw it could understand it and felt the fun, was a huge sign to me. Unfortunately, not every game has a premise that allows for that. I don't think you could hope for the same kind of feeling while making a 4X for example.<p>But if you're making a game that ultimately should feel fun from moment to moment, like these kind of quick-play games are, well, I think you can get there quickly and with little work, if the idea is solid. And if you can't get it to feel fun, I would be wondering if the idea is solid, versus it needing more time/polish etc.</p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189325&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189325" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190014"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="2"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="80"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190014&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190014"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=protocolture">protocolture</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T00:35:42 1740616542"><a href="item?id=43190014">5 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190014"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189122">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189325">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189442">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190014" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">&gt;I can't comment on the reality of a 3d game with a complicated art pipeline, however. But for a game like Ballionaire, Unity or Unreal would have been a mistake.<p>Going from Zero to Working 3d Game is very quick in Unity as long as you do everything the Unity way.<p>Going from Zero to Working 3d Game if you need to create functionality from scratch in Unity is a heartbreaker.<p>I am actually planning to take one of my old projects and rebuild it from scratch in Godot, for exactly this reason.</p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190014&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343190014" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189442"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189442&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189442"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=japhib">japhib</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T23:22:15 1740612135"><a href="item?id=43189442">7 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189442"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189122">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189325">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190084">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189442" n="2">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">&gt; I realise you can make games in any language/engine<p>It's actually a bit more constrained than people realize ... Well, for desktop, you can literally use anything. But for mobile it's a bit harder because of specific platform quirks, i.e. on iOS you can't make a language that relies on a JIT compiler, so for a Java/libGDX game the best option is <a href="https://github.com/MobiVM/robovm">https://github.com/MobiVM/robovm</a> which compiles the JVM bytecode to LLVM IR and then to native machine code.<p>And then for consoles (switch/xbox/ps5) it's way worse because you're relying on commercial stuff, and the only support you get is from the engine makers themselves (Nintendo/Microsoft/Sony) so there's a lot less open source options. Basically you're stuck with C++ at that point (which Unity actually compiles your C# to under the hood for non-desktop platforms).<p>Not what you asked, but I found out this stuff a while back and find it interesting, hopefully it's interesting to you too :)</p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189442&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189442" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189501"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="2"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="80"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189501&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189501"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=neonsunset">neonsunset</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T23:29:50 1740612590"><a href="item?id=43189501">6 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189501"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189122">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189442">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190084">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189501" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Technically you can ship an FNA-based game with a commercial fork of .NET's NativeAOT that works on Nintendo Switch: <a href="https://viridiansoftware.com/blog/csharp-on-game-consoles" rel="nofollow">https://viridiansoftware.com/blog/csharp-on-game-consoles</a> Of course Xbox can just ship C#-written game normally AFAIK. So it's not like you're stuck with just C++ but yes, mobile platforms usually are highly constraining.</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189501&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189501" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

<div class="commtext c00">I started trying to make games as soon as I got an Apple //c when I was like 9 years old. I went to MSFT out of college but quit to work on games like a year into it. My first games job was at Monolith (RIP as of yesterday) and was there for ~4 years, then I helped S2 Games ship "Savage: Battle for Newerth, but then went into FAANG for like 20 years. I always wanted to come back to gamedev. Glad I got the chance :)</div>

<div class="commtext c00">Thank you! I absolutely suck at game jams. Like, really bad. Ballionaire is the one time a gamejam (<a href="https://itch.io/jam/eggjam-20" rel="nofollow">https://itch.io/jam/eggjam-20</a>) went right for me (good idea, microscopic scope) - you can see a video from about ~10 days into development here: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CwIwcGewZME" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CwIwcGewZME</a><p>Normally I either scope way too big, or scope small and lose motivation because the idea is too itty bitty to maintain motivation. I have no idea how to hit the sweet spot more frequently. Some people are just really good at this, but not me.<p>For insurance: private insurance via ACA/Obamacare. I had savings.</p></p></div>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190018"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190018&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190018"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=mattigames">mattigames</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T00:35:55 1740616555"><a href="item?id=43190018">5 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190018"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190064">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190112">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190018" n="3">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">What is your opinion about the top bad review on Steam? Have you addressed those issues or perhaps you disagree with them? Posted here for reference<p>&gt; Really fun game at first, and it has a lot of potential. Unfortunately you are very strongly incentivized to NOT UNLOCK ANYTHING (i.e. the meta-progression).... because after you unlock many additional items and get to the higher difficulties, the vast majority of runs become impossible since there are way, way too many items in the pool and way, way too few rerolls (and no ban feature for some reason), so you end up with random unrelated crap almost every run and auto-lose because of it, as strong synergies are mandatory to win on the higher difficulties. It feels really bad having to fish RNG over and over again just to get a run that's actually winnable. They could easily fix this with many solutions, like: stronger reroll tag affinities, more choices per round, item bans, 10x the amount of rerolls, builds/profiles with more limited pools, map-specific limited pools, etc. etc. If they fix this massive roadblock then this game has the potential to be a amazingly fun.</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190018&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343190018" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190070"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190070&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190070"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=newobj">newobj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T00:43:21 1740617001"><a href="item?id=43190070">5 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190070"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190018">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190112">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190070" n="2">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">It was intentional that the game got harder by broadening the pool of drafts. The design goal was that you need to develop your skill to build more flexible boards, that don't rely on just forcing a single synergy to materialize.<p>Unfortunately, I don't think the game communicates this goal well, AND prevailing design trends (rogueli<i>T</i>e, which this game is NOT) I think have trained players to expect that games should get artificially EASIER over time by increasing the player's power level.<p>It's a point of the design I'm willing to concede, so it's something I do hope to address. But not increasing the power level as in a roguelite, just by preserving the density of drafts and taming dilution a bit.</p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190070&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343190070" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190786"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="2"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="80"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190786&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190786"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=martinmakesgame">martinmakesgame</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T02:46:14 1740624374"><a href="item?id=43190786">3 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190786"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190018">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190070">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190112">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190786" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">The widening of the pool of drafts doesn't work because it is not fun. When you find something that works you want to use it as much as possible because as the player all I want to see is the numbers get higher and higher. This is where the fun is. Most of the additional drafts aren't fun. Some I never use. When I play I don't even care about the forces that make it harder at the start anymore because most of the gameplay comes from what cards show which is heavy random number generator. There should be a continue play button when you fail the run though just so you can keep playing and see the numbers go higher and higher.</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190786&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343190786" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189298"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189298&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189298"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">

<div class="commtext c00">Congratulations! That's a huge accomplishment, and not something I'd call "minor."<p>When I think about game development, these are the skills and types of work that come to mind:<p>- software development<p>- game design<p>- graphical art<p>- musical composition<p>- writing<p>- marketing and promotion<p>and I'm sure there's more that I'm missing. I'd be very curious to know how you navigated through all of that...like did you start on one end, like with a game engine, and then fill in the rest, or was it more of a holistic iterative process? I hope that's not too broad of a question, but frankly I'd appreciate any insights you can share.</p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></div>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189851"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">

</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">There are a lot of interpretations, but it's roguelike in the sense that:<p>1) It's permadeath
2) It's random
3) It's systemic<p>The term is used quite broadly these days. Only the "Berlin interpretation" is quite strict about the sense of it you might be thinking of.</p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189851&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189851" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190755"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="2"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="80"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190755&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190755"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=joemi">joemi</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T02:41:00 1740624060"><a href="item?id=43190755">3 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190755"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189702">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189851">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189872">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190755" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Is there a term that people who don't use the Berlin interpretation call games that fit in the Berlin interpretation? Or are they just called "Berlin interpretation roguelikes"?<p>(I'm asking both out of curiosity and out of utility, since I'm a fan of the Berlin interpretation roguelikes (and have been since before the modern overly-broad interpretation came into use), so I used to be able to count on "roguelike" meaning it was one style of game, and I miss those days. I'd like to be able to know how to specifically find those games again.)<p>Also, congrats on the success of the game! I'm looking forward to trying it out sometime. It's on my wishlist, despite my quibbles with calling it a roguelike.  :)</p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">

<div class="commtext c00">Use every sale period available to you and not as weekly sales. Make custom 14 day sales.<p>Add steam cards to the game asap. You should start doing this right after reading this comment really.<p>Also you should lobby steam for a daily deal sometime next month. If they say yes you should set that daily deal for the day the summer sale ends if you can.<p>Also you should push raw fury to do a publisher sale, those can really generate a lot of money.<p>I've been managing games on Steam for a long time and doing stuff like what I said will have a very large impact on your long tail revenue. I'm the game director of Kingmakers.<p>Also you should really have some kind of DLC asap, even if it is small or like an art book even. You are just leaving money on the table because there are gamers with lots of money on steam who just buy all the dlc when they buy games.</p></p></p></p></p></div>

<div class="commtext c00">what engine did you use? anything you would you have done differently in hindsight?</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189121&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189121" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189248"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189248&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189248"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=newobj">newobj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T22:57:17 1740610637"><a href="item?id=43189248">7 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189248"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189121">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189974">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189248" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Godot 4.2 with C#. Done differently? Hmm. It was an intense duration of work and I set a firm deadline for myself of EOY 2024 to avoid it dragging out into a longer-than-it-should-be project. Gaining design skills along the way, I could make better use of the same amount of time now, just by being a better designer. But that's not hindsight. There were trade-offs in that aggressive schedule, and a lot of triaging. One of the things that probably could have used a little more time in the oven, perhaps trading off against content, was the meta progression. I wasn't in love with what shipped, and it seems to be the main criticism of the game, besides RNG. It's something I may still potentially address in a patch though.</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189248&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343189248" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<center><a href="vote?id=43189804&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43189804"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">

             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190291">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189139">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189804" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Congrats on your success! Making games is what got me into programming and while I'm currently doing the same big tech stuff you were, I would love to become an indie game dev after this phase of my career ends.<p>The biggest challenge I've had in my various personal projects is the art, for sure. I may have programming skills but I certainly have no art or animation skills. How did you get over this hurdle? I've made so many cool prototypes for games that I end up having to shelve due to hitting a progress wall when it comes to art or 3d modeling.</p></div>

<div class="commtext c5A">I still don't really get the appeal of roguelike games, to me it always just comes off either repetitive/boring/frustrating/etc. Could someone explain why they prefer it over just a "normal" game progression?</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190534"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190534&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406" id="up_43190534"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=sky2224">sky2224</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T02:08:56 1740622136"><a href="item?id=43190534">4 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190534"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190328">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190065">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190534" n="2">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Maybe this will help a bit.  I'm a drummer.  Drums are literally all about doing the exact same thing for hours and hours on end, but with the goal of perfection.  What's perfection?  That's all in the eyes of the player.  Been doing it 15+ years and don't plan on stopping.<p>I can do repetitive stuff like that for hours on end.  A roguelike takes that and makes it a game with some slight variation to keep it interesting (kind of how a drum beat is the same thing, and then you change it to add some variation).</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190534&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43186406%2343190534" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

algorithm introduced in the \u003ca href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/2412.19437\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDeepSeek-V3 Technical Report\u003c/a\u003e. It achieves full overlap of forward and backward computation-communication phases, also reducing pipeline bubbles. For detailed information on computation-communication overlap, please refer to the \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/deepseek-ai/profile-data\"\u003eprofile data\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eSchedules\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-schedules\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Schedules\" href=\"#schedules\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" href=\"/deepseek-ai/DualPipe/blob/main/images/schedules.png\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"/deepseek-ai/DualPipe/raw/main/images/schedules.png\" alt=\"schedules\" style=\"max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eExample DualPipe scheduling for 8 PP ranks and 20 micro-batches in two directions.\nThe micro-batches in the reverse direction are symmetric to those in the forward direction, so\nwe omit their batch ID for illustration simplicity. Two cells enclosed by a shared black border\nhave mutually overlapped computation and communication\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003ePipeline Bubbles and Memory Usage Comparison\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-pipeline-bubbles-and-memory-usage-comparison\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Pipeline Bubbles and Memory Usage Comparison\" href=\"#pipeline-bubbles-and-memory-usage-comparison\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 0 dir=\"auto\"\u003e𝐹 denotes the execution time of a forward chunk, 𝐵 denotes the execution time of a\nfull backward chunk, 𝑊 denotes the execution time of a \"backward for weights\" chunk, and 𝐹\u0026amp;𝐵\ndenotes the execution time of two mutually overlapped forward and backward chunks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\"
