2Z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="Box-sc-g0xbh4-0 QkQOb js-snippet-clipboard-copy-unpositioned undefined" data-hpc="true"><article class="markdown-body entry-content container-lg" itemprop="text"><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h1 class="heading-element" dir="auto" tabindex="-1">DualPipe</h1><a aria-label="Permalink: DualPipe" class="anchor" href="#dualpipe" id="user-content-dualpipe"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewbox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">DualPipe is an innovative bidirectional pipeline parallelism algorithm introduced in the <a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/2412.19437" rel="nofollow">DeepSeek-V3 Technical Report</a>. It achieves full overlap of forward and backward computation-communication phases, also reducing pipeline bubbles. For detailed information on computation-communication overlap, please refer to the <a href="https://github.com/deepseek-ai/profile-data">profile data</a>.</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 class="heading-element" dir="auto" tabindex="-1">Schedules</h3><a aria-label="Permalink: Schedules" class="anchor" href="#schedules" id="user-content-schedules"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewbox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><a href="/deepseek-ai/DualPipe/blob/main/images/schedules.png" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"><img alt="schedules" src="/deepseek-ai/DualPipe/raw/main/images/schedules.png" style="max-width: 100%;"/></a></p>
<p dir="auto">Example DualPipe scheduling for 8 PP ranks and 20 micro-batches in two directions.
The micro-batches in the reverse direction are symmetric to those in the forward direction, so
we omit their batch ID for illustration simplicity. Two cells enclosed by a shared black border
have mutually overlapped computation and communication</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 class="heading-element" dir="auto" tabindex="-1">Pipeline Bubbles and Memory Usage Comparison</h3><a aria-label="Permalink: Pipeline Bubbles and Memory Usage Comparison" class="anchor" href="#pipeline-bubbles-and-memory-usage-comparison" id="user-content-pipeline-bubbles-and-memory-usage-comparison"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewbox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<markdown-accessiblity-table><table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Method</th>
<th>Bubble</th>
<th>Parameter</th>
<th>Activation</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>1F1B</td>
<td>(PP-1)(𝐹+𝐵)</td>
<td>1×</td>
<td>PP</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>ZB1P</td>
<td>(PP-1)(𝐹+𝐵-2𝑊)</td>
<td>1×</td>
<td>PP</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>DualPipe</td>
<td>(PP/2-1)(𝐹&amp;𝐵+𝐵-3𝑊)</td>
<td>2×</td>
<td>PP+1</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table></markdown-accessiblity-table>
<p dir="auto">𝐹 denotes the execution time of a forward chunk, 𝐵 denotes the execution time of a
full backward chunk, 𝑊 denotes the execution time of a "backward for weights" chunk, and 𝐹&amp;𝐵
denotes the execution time of two mutually overlapped forward and backward chunks.</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 class="heading-element" dir="auto" tabindex="-1">Quick Start</h2><a aria-label="Permalink: Quick Start" class="anchor" href="#quick-start" id="user-content-quick-start"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewbox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">The usage is shown in the following example:</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="python example.py" dir="auto"><pre>python example.py</pre></div>
<p dir="auto">Note: For real-world applications, you will need to implement a custom <code>overlapped_forward_backward</code> method tailored to your specific module.</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 class="heading-element" dir="auto" tabindex="-1">Requirements</h2><a aria-label="Permalink: Requirements" class="anchor" href="#requirements" id="user-content-requirements"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewbox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>PyTorch 2.0 and above</li>
</ul>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 class="heading-element" dir="auto" tabindex="-1">Developers</h2><a aria-label="Permalink: Developers" class="anchor" href="#developers" id="user-content-developers"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewbox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">DualPipe was created and developed by Jiashi Li and Chengqi Deng and Wenfeng Liang.</p>

<section class="wrapper align-center" id="twoandahalf" style="background-color:transparent; color:white; position:relative">
<div class="inner"><center>
<div id="animation" style="position:absolute; top:0; left:0; z-index:-1; width:100%; height:100%; background:#6cc091">
<script>
	Algebra(3,1,()=>{ 
	  var ni = 1e4+1e3,           // n-infinite
	      no = .5e4-.5e3;         // n-origin
	  var point  = (x,y)=>no + x*1e1 + y*1e2 + 0.5*(x*x+y*y)*ni;
	  var circles = [...Array(16)].map((x,i)=>
			[...Array(16)].map((y,j)=>!(point(0.25+0.5*(i-8),0.25+0.5*(j-8))-0.25**2/2*ni))).flat();
	  
	  var svg = document.querySelector("#animation").appendChild(this.graph(()=>{
	    var t = performance.now()/8000,
		t2 = Math.sin(t/2.315)*2; 
	    var C = !(no - 0.5*ni),       
		D = point(t2*(Math.sin(t)**3),t2*(Math.cos(t)**3)) + !(-0.5*ni);
	    return [0x7cd0a1, ...D*C >>> circles]
	  },{conformal:true,lineWidth:20, scale:4, animate:1}));
	  svg.style.background='transparent';              
	  svg.style.width ='100%';
	  svg.style.height='100%';
	});      
    </script>
</div>

<!--section id="three" class="wrapper align-center" style="background-color:#6cc091; color:white">
				<div class="inner align-center" style="display: flex;align-items: center;justify-content: center;">
                                <div class="conference" style="display:inline-block;"><a title="SIGGRAPH Conference" href="https://www.siggraph.org/current-conference" href="https://www.siggraph.org/current-conference"><img style="border: none;" src="https://media.siggraph.org/promo/siggraph-badge.gif" src="https://media.siggraph.org/promo/siggraph-badge.gif" alt="SIGGRAPH" width="160" height="64" /></a></div>

<!-- Three -->
<section class="wrapper align-center" id="three">
<div class="inner">
<!--
				        <p>We may always depend on it that algebra, which cannot be translated into good English and sound common sense, is bad algebra.<br>
				        <span style="padding-left:400px">William Kingdon Clifford</span>
				        </p>
				        -->
<p style="max-width:800px; margin:auto; margin-bottom:3em; font-size:110%; ">
				        Clifford's <b>Geometric Algebra</b> enables a unified, intuitive and fresh perspective
				        on vector spaces, giving elements of arbitrary dimensionality a natural home.
				        </p>
<div class="flex flex-2">
<article>
<div class="image round" id="vector">
<!--img src="images/pic01.jpg" alt="Pic 01" /-->
</div>
<script>
							// Create a Clifford Algebra with 3,0,1 metric. 
							Algebra(3,0,1,()=>{

							// rotation helper and Lathe function.     
							var rot = (a,P)=>Math.cos(a)+Math.sin(a)*P.Normalized,
							    lathe=(X,n,P,m)=>[...Array(n+1)].map((x,i)=>rot(i/n*Math.PI*(m||1),P)>>>X),

							// wrap takes X, a double array of points, and generates triangles.    
							    wrap=(X)=>{ 
							      var u=X.length-1,v=X[0].length-1; X=[].concat.apply([],X);
							      var P=[],vp=v+1; for(var i=0;i<u*vp;i+=vp)for(var j=0;j<v;j++)P.push([i+j,i+j+1,vp+i+j],[i+j+1,vp+i+j,vp+i+j+1]);
							      return P.map(x=>x.map(x=>X[x]));
							    },
							    
							// Basic primitives constructed by Lathing points, line segments, etc.    
							    cylinder = (r=1,h=1,x=32)=>wrap(lathe([!1e0,!(1e0+r*1e3),!(1e0+r*1e3+h*1e1),!(1e0+h*1e1)],x,1e23)),
							    torus    = (r=.3,r2=.25,x=32,y=16)=>wrap(lathe((1+r*.5e03)>>>lathe(!(1e0+r2*(1e1+1e3)/2**.5),y,1e13),x,1e23)),
							    sphere   = (r=1,x=32,y=16)=>wrap(lathe(lathe(!(1e0+r*1e1),y,1e13,.5),x,1e23)),
							    cone     = (r=1,h=1,x=64)=>wrap(lathe([!1e0,!(1e0+r*1e3),!(1e0+h*1e1)],x,1e23)),
							    arrow    = ()=>[...cone(.075,.2),...cone(.075,0),...cylinder(.03,-1)],
							    
							// A selection of these objects.     
							    objs=[arrow()].map(x=>({data:x}));
							      
							// Render and rotate them using the webGL2 previewer.      
							  var c=document.getElementById('vector').appendChild( this.graph(()=>{
							    var time = Math.PI/2+-.5*Math.sin(performance.now()/1000);
							    objs.forEach((obj,i)=>obj.transform = rot(time,1e13)*rot(-0.1,1e12)*(1-.5e01));
							    return [0x00ff88,...objs]
							  },{gl:1,alpha:1,animate:0,camera:(1-.7e03)*Math.E**(Math.PI/4*1e13),grid:0}));    
							  c.style.width=c.style.height='150px';
							});							
							</script>
<header>
<h3>The Vector</h3>
<p>
							The <b>Vector</b> is an oriented, <b>one dimensional</b><br/>
							quantity. Two $\parallel$ <b>Vectors</b> multiply to a <b>Scalar</b> ($\mathbb R$).<br/>
							Two $\perp$ vectors <b>anti-commute</b> ($e_1e_2=-e_2e_1$)
							</p>
</header>
<!--footer>
								<a href="doc.html" class="button">Learn More</a>
							</footer-->
</article>
<article>
<div class="image round" id="bivector">
<!--img src="images/pic02.jpg" alt="Pic 02"/-->
</div>
<script>
								Algebra(3,0,1,()=>{

								// rotation helper and Lathe function.     
								var rot = (a,P)=>Math.E**(a*P.Normalized),
								    lathe=(X,n,P,m)=>[...Array(n+1)].map((x,i)=>rot(i/n*Math.PI*(m||1),P)>>>X),

								// wrap takes X, a double array of points, and generates triangles.    
								    wrap=(X)=>{ 
								      var u=X.length-1,v=X[0].length-1; X=[].concat.apply([],X);
								      var P=[],vp=v+1; for(var i=0;i<u*vp;i+=vp)for(var j=0;j<v;j++)P.push([i+j,i+j+1,vp+i+j],[i+j+1,vp+i+j,vp+i+j+1]);
								      return P.map(x=>x.map(x=>X[x]));
								    },
								    
								// Basic primitives constructed by Lathing points, line segments, etc.    
								    cylinder = (r=1,h=1,x=32)=>wrap(lathe([!1e0,!(1e0+r*1e3),!(1e0+r*1e3+h*1e1),!(1e0+h*1e1)],x,1e23)),
								    torus    = (r=.3,r2=.25,x=32,y=16)=>wrap(lathe((1+r*.5e03)>>>lathe(!(1e0+r2*(1e1+1e3)/2**.5),y,1e13),x,1e23)),
								    sphere   = (r=1,x=32,y=16)=>wrap(lathe(lathe(!(1e0+r*1e1),y,1e13,.5),x,1e23)),
								    cone     = (r=1,h=1,x=64)=>wrap(lathe([!1e0,!(1e0+r*1e3),!(1e0+h*1e1)],x,1e23)),
								    arrow    = ()=>(1-0.5e01)>>>[/*...cone(.075,0),*/...cone(.075,.2),...cylinder(.03,-1)],
								    
								// A selection of these objects.     
								    objs=[arrow(),arrow()].map(x=>({data:x}));
								      
								// Render and rotate them using the webGL2 previewer.      
								  var c=document.getElementById('bivector').appendChild( this.graph(()=>{
								    var time = Math.PI/2+-.5*Math.sin(performance.now()/1000);
								    var time2 = Math.PI/2+-.5*Math.sin(performance.now()/2134);
								    var t1 = objs[0].transform = rot(time,1e13)*rot(-0.1,1e12)*(1-.0e01);
								    var t2 = objs[1].transform = rot(time2,1e12+.5e23)*rot(-0.1,1e12)*(1-.0e01);
								    return [0xbbaaffaa,...objs, 0xff0000, [1e123,t1>>>!(1e0+1e1),t2>>>!(1e0+1e1)]] 
								  },{gl:1,alpha:1,animate:1,camera:(1-.7e03)*Math.E**(Math.PI/4*1e13),grid:0}));    
								  c.style.width=c.style.height='150px';
								});
                                                        </script>
<header>
<h3>The Bivector</h3>
<p>
							The <b>Bivector</b> is an oriented, <b>two dimensional</b><br/>
							quantity. <b>Bivectors</b> naturally represent<br/> <b>transformations</b>.
							Similarly, $n$ vectors combine into an $n$-vector.
							</p>
</header>
<!--footer>
								<a href="doc.html" class="button">Learn More</a>
							</footer-->
</article>
</div>
</div>
</section>
<section class="wrapper align-center" id="four">
<div class="inner">
<p style="max-width:800px; margin:auto; font-size:110%">
					The $n$-dimensional <b>geometric algebra</b> $\mathbb R_{p,q,r}$ is constructed
					from $p$ <b>positive</b>, $q$ <b>negative</b> and $r$ <b>null</b> vectors
					called <b>generators</b>, written $\bf e_i$  
					</p>
<div class="flex flex-2">
<article>
<div class="image round" id="scalar">
<div style="font-size:130px">$\mathbb R$</div>
<!--img src="images/pic02.jpg" alt="Pic 02"/-->
</div>
<header>
<h3>The Scalar</h3>
<p>
							The <b>Scalars $\mathbb R$</b> are included in <br/>
							the algebras. every basis <b>$n$-vector</b><br/> squares
							to a Real Number.<br/>
</p>
</header>
<!--footer>
								<a href="doc.html" class="button">Learn More</a>
							</footer-->
</article>
<article>
<div class="image round" id="rotors">
<!--DIV style="font-size:150px">$\mathbb R^+$</DIV-->
<div style="font-size:130px">$e^{\mathbf e_{ij}}$</div>
</div>
<header>
<h3>The Rotor</h3>
<p>
							The product of two <b>vectors</b>, or the<br/>
<b>exponentiation</b> of a  <b>bivector</b> creates<br/>
							a rotor. (rotation, translation, ..)
							</p>
</header>
<!--footer>
								<a href="doc.html" class="button">Learn More</a>
							</footer-->
</article>
</div>
<p style="max-width:800px; margin:auto;margin-bottom:3em; text-align:center">
					A generic element of the algebra is called a <b>multivector</b> and is
					a linear combination of <b>scalar</b>, <b>vector</b> and <b>$n$-vector</b> parts.<b>
					$$\mathbf X = \alpha_0 + \alpha_1 \mathbf e_1 + .. + \alpha_i \mathbf e_{12} + .. + \alpha_n \mathbf e_{12..n} $$
					</b>
</p>
<footer>
<a class="button" href="doc.html">Learn more</a>
</footer>
</div>
</section>
<section class="wrapper align-center" id="four">
<div class="inner">
<h3>Vectorspace Geometric Algebra</h3>
<p style="max-width:800px; margin:auto; margin-bottom:3em; font-size:110%">
					The Geometric Algebras for the 2D and 3D vectors naturally
					include 2D and 3D rotations.
					</p>
<div class="flex flex-2">
<article>
<div class="image round" id="scalar">
<div style="font-size:60px;margin-bottom:60px;">$\mathbb R_2^+ \cong \mathbb C$</div>
</div>
<header>
<h3>2D Vectors</h3>
<p>
							The geometric algebra $\mathbb R_2$ of the <br/>
<b>2D Vectors</b> has the <b>complex numbers</b><br/>
							as its even subalgebra.
							</p>
</header>
<!--footer>
								<a href="doc.html" class="button">Learn More</a>
							</footer-->
</article>
<article>
<div class="image round" id="scalar">
<div style="font-size:60px;margin-bottom:60px;">$\mathbb R_3^+ \cong \mathbb H$</div>
</div>
<header>
<h3>3D Vectors</h3>
<p>
							The geometric algebra $\mathbb R_3$ of the <br/>
<b>3D Vectors</b> has the <b>quaternions</b><br/>
							as its even subalgebra.
							</p>
</header>
<!--footer>
								<a href="doc.html" class="button">Learn More</a>
							</footer-->
</article>
</div>
</div>
</section>
<section class="wrapper align-center" id="five">
<div class="inner">
<h3>Projective Geometric Algebra</h3>
<p style="max-width:1000px; margin:auto; margin-bottom:3em; font-size:110%">
					Using one extra dimension, we obtain the plane-based <b>Projective Geometric Algebra</b>
					for 2 and 3 dimensions. Its elements are <b>points</b>, <b>lines</b> and <b>planes</b>. It
					includes elements at <b>infinity</b> and has exception free <b>join</b> and <b>meet</b> operations.
					Its even subalgebra provides in rotations &amp; translations and is isomorphic to the <b>dual quaternions</b>
</p>
<div class="flex flex-2">
<article>
<div class="image round trap" id="2dpga">
</div>
<script>
							var PGA2D = (onoff)=>{
							// Create a Clifford Algebra with 2,0,1 metric. 
							return Algebra(2,0,1).inline((onoff)=>{
							  
							  // The identities we already established.
							  var point = (x,y)=>1e12-x*1e02+y*1e01,    
							      line  = (a,b,c)=>a*1e1+b*1e2+c*1e0;
							      
							  // Distances and angles
							  var dist_pp = (X,Y)=>(X&Y).Length,
							      dist_pl = (P,l)=>(P.Normalized^l.Normalized).e012,
							      angle   = (x,y)=>Math.acos(x.Normalized<<y.Normalized);

							  var A=()=>point(-1,0.5*Math.sin(0.0005*performance.now())),  // expression on time
							      B=point(-1,-1), C=point(1,-1); 
							  
							  // Define some algebraic expressions as functions of these points.
							  var AB=()=>B&A, BC =()=>C&B, CA=()=>C&A;

							  // Distances between points as functions that return labels (strings);
							  var AtoB   =()=>dist_pp(A,B).toFixed(3),  
							      BtoC   =()=>dist_pp(C,B).toFixed(3),     
							      CtoA   =()=>dist_pp(C,A).toFixed(3);

							  // Angles between lines as strings (labels for the points)
							  var  CAtoAB =()=>((angle(CA,AB)*180/Math.PI)|0)+'&deg;', 
							       ABtoBC =()=>((angle(AB,-BC)*180/Math.PI)|0)+'&deg;',
							       CAtoBC =()=>((angle(CA,BC)*180/Math.PI)|0)+'&deg;';

							  // Distance between point and line.
							  var BtoCA  =()=>dist_pl(B,CA).toFixed(3);

							  // Graph the triangle, its angles and side lengths.
							  var con = document.getElementById('2dpga');
							  while (con.firstChild) con.removeChild(con.firstChild);
							  var c=document.getElementById('2dpga').appendChild(this.graph([
							    0xffcccc, [A,B,C],                              // render the triangle
							    0xff4444, AB, AtoB, BC, BtoC, CA, CtoA,         // render edges and lengths.
							    0x444444, A, CAtoAB, B, ABtoBC, C, CAtoBC,      // render verts and angles
							    0x8888ff, [B,()=>(CA<<B)*CA], BtoCA, 
							  ],{grid:false,animate:onoff,fontSize:3,pointRadius:2,scale:1.5,lineWidth:6}));
							  c.style.background='transparent';
							  c.style.width=c.style.height='180px'
							  c.remake = PGA2D;
							  return c;
							})(onoff);
							}
							PGA2D(false);
							</script>
<header>
<h3>$\mathbb R^*_{2,0,1}$ : 2D PGA</h3>
<p>
							In <b>2D PGA</b> points <b>join</b> $\vee$ into <br \=""/>
							lines and lines <b>meet</b> $\wedge$ into points.<br \=""/>
<b>Rotations</b> and <b>translations</b> are unified,<br \=""/>
							with bivectors isomorphic to $\mathfrak{SE}(2)$
							</p>
</header>
<footer>
<a class="button" href="doc.html">Learn More</a>
</footer>
</article>
<article>
<div class="image round trap" id="3dpga">
</div>
<script>
							// Create a Clifford Algebra with 3,0,1 metric. 
							var PGA3D = (onoff)=>Algebra(3,0,1).inline((onoff)=>{ 
							    
							  // Specify a point directly (trivectors specified with overloaded e-notation.)
							  var point = (x,y,z)=>1e123-x*1e012-y*1e013+z*1e023;
							  
							  // Lines can be defined using plucker coordinates
							  var line = (px,py,pz,dx,dy,dz)=>px*1e01+py&1e02+pz*1e03+dx*1e12+dy*1e13+dz*1e23;

							  // Planes can be defined directly using e0,e1,e2,e3
							  var plane = (a,b,c,d)=>d*1e0+a*1e1+b*1e2+c*1e3;
							  
							  // Useful distances
							  var dist_pp = (P1,P2)=>(P1.Normalized&P2.Normalized).Length,    // point to point
							      dist_pP = (P,p)=>(P.Normalized&p.Normalized).Length,        // point to plane
							      dist_ll = (l1,l2)=>(!(l1.Normalized*l2.Normalized)).Length; // line to line
							  
							  // Useful angles
							  var angle_pp = (p1,p2)=>Math.acos(p1.Normalized<<p2.Normalized)*180/Math.PI, // Angle between planes
							      angle_ll = (l1,l2)=>Math.acos(l1.Normalized<<l2.Normalized)*180/Math.PI; // Angle between lines 
							  
							  // Create 5 points.
							  var A=point(0,-1,0), B=point(1,1,-1), C=point(-1,1,-1), D=point(1,1,1), E=point(-1,1,1), 
							  
							  // Our ground plane
							      a=B&C&D,
							  
							  // Our camera position and orientation
							      camera=0e0;
							  
							  // Graph the 3D items
							  var con=document.getElementById('3dpga');
							  while(con.firstChild)con.removeChild(con.firstChild);
							  var c=document.getElementById('3dpga').appendChild(this.graph(()=>{
							    var time=performance.now()/4000;    
							    A=point(0,Math.sin(time*4),0);
							    camera.set((Math.cos(time)+Math.sin(time)*1e13)*(1-0.2e02));                      // rotate around Y 
							    return [0xddaaff,[A,B,C],                                            // graph on face
								    0xAA88FF,[A,B],[A,C],[A,D],[B,C],[B,D],[C,E],[A,E],[E,D],    // graph all edges
								    0x444444,A,"A",B,"B",C,"C",D,"D",E,"E",                      // graph all vertices
								    0xFF8888,[A,E],dist_pp(A,E).toFixed(2),                      // distance A to E
								    0x8888FF,[A,B+E],dist_pP(A,a).toFixed(2),                    // distance A to a
								    0x44aa44,C+E,dist_ll(C&E,D&B).toFixed(2),                    // distance CE to DB
								    0x44aaff,[A+D+E,B+C+5*D+5*E,D+E],(angle_pp(A&E&D,a).toFixed(2))+"B0",   // angle planes.
								    0xff44ff,[A,2*A+D,2*A+B],(angle_ll(A&D,B&A).toFixed(2))+"B0"
								   ];
							  },{animate:onoff,camera,scale:1.3,fontSize:3,pointRadius:2,lineWidth:8})); 
							  c.style.background='transparent';
							  c.style.width=c.style.height='170px'
							  c.remake = PGA3D;
							  return c;
							  
							})(onoff);
							PGA3D(false);							
							</script>
<header>
<h3>$\mathbb R^*_{3,0,1}$ : 3D PGA</h3>
<p>
							In <b>3D PGA</b> points and lines <b>join</b> $\vee$ into <br \=""/>
							lines and planes, while lines and planes <b>meet</b> $\wedge$<br \=""/>
							into points and lines. The bivectors are isomorphic<br \=""/>
							to $\mathfrak{SE}(3)$, the <b>dual quaternions</b>
</p>
</header>
<footer>
<a class="button" href="doc.html">Learn More</a>
</footer>
</article>
</div>
</div>
</section>
<section class="wrapper align-center" id="sox">
<div class="inner">
<h3>Conformal Geometric Algebra</h3>
<p style="max-width:1000px; margin:auto; margin-bottom:3em; font-size:110%">
					Using two extra dimensions, we obtain the point-based <b>Conformal Geometric Algebra</b>
					for 2 and 3 dimensions. Its elements are <b>points</b>, <b>point pairs</b>, <b>lines</b>, <b>circles</b>, <b>spheres</b> and <b>planes</b>. It
					includes an infinite point and has exception free <b>join</b> and <b>meet</b> operations.
					Its even subalgebra provides in <b>conformal transformations</b>.
</p>
<div class="flex flex-2">
<article>
<div class="image round trap" id="2dcga">
</div>
<script>
							// Create a Clifford Algebra with 3,1 metric for 2D CGA. 
							var CGA2D = Algebra(3,1).inline((onoff)=>{ 

							// Two null vectors to work with (called origin and infinite)
							  var ei = 1e4-1e3,           // e-infinite
							      eo = 0.5*(1e4+1e3);     // e-origin
							  
							// Define points, lines, circles using the null basis.  
							  var point  = (x,y)=>eo + x*1e1 + y*1e2 + 0.5*(x*x+y*y)*ei,
							      line   = (a,b,c)=>!(a*1e1 + b*1e2 + c*ei),
							      circle = (x,y,r)=>!(point(x,y) - r**2/2*ei);
							  
							// Some identities
							  var line_through_P_parallel_with_X = (P,X)=>(P^ei)<<X*(P^ei),
							      project_point_on_circle        = (P,C)=>(P^ei)<<C*C,
							      project_point_on_line          = (P,L)=>P<<L.Normalized*L.Normalized,
							      position                       = (X)=>{ X=X/(X^ei); return X/(X<<-ei); },
							      radius                         = (X)=>Math.abs(((X<<X).s/((X^ei)**2).s))**.5,
							      attitude                       = (X)=>(ei^eo<<(X^ei)).Normalized,
							      split                          = (pp)=>position(pp)-radius(pp)*attitude(pp);

							// Define some elements.
							  var p1 = point(-0.7,0.4), p2 = point(1,-0.5), p3 = point(0,1.5),
							      D = circle(1,-1,0.7),
							      X = line(0,1,0), Y=()=>p2^p3^ei;
							      
							// Graph 
							  var con = document.getElementById('2dcga');
							  while (con.firstChild) con.removeChild(con.firstChild);
							  var c = con.appendChild(this.graph([
							    0xFF8888, ()=>{ D=circle(1,-1,0.7+0.3*Math.sin(performance.now()/1234)); return D},                                        // circle
							    ()=>position(D), ()=>"D "+(radius(D).toFixed(2)),   // Center,Radius
							    0x44AA44, X, "X", Y, "Y",                           // lines
							    0x4444FF,
							    ()=>line_through_P_parallel_with_X(p1,Y),"p&parallel;Y", // parallel to line
							    ()=>line_through_P_parallel_with_X(p1,D),"p&parallel;D", // parallel to circle
							    0xFF44FF, 
							    ()=>split(project_point_on_circle(p1,D)),"p&rarr;D", // project on circle
							    ()=>project_point_on_line(p1,X), "p&rarr;X",         // project on line
							    ()=>project_point_on_line(p1,Y), "p&rarr;Y",         // project on line
							    0x444444,()=>{ p1=point(-0.7*Math.cos(performance.now()/2234),0.7*Math.sin(performance.now()/2234)); return p1; },
							    ()=>D&Y,"Y &vee; D"
							  ],{fontSize:2,lineWidth:4,pointRadius:2,conformal:true,animate:onoff,grid:false}));                       // conformal flag!  
                                                        
							  c.style.background='transparent';
							  c.style.width=c.style.height='180px'
							  c.remake = CGA2D;
							  return c;
							});
							CGA2D(false);
							</script>
<header>
<h3>$\mathbb R_{3,1}$ : 2D CGA</h3>
<p>
							In <b>2D CGA</b>, points <b>join</b> ($\wedge$) into lines<br>
							and circles, and lines and circles <b>meet</b> ($\vee$) in points.<br>
<b>Rotations</b>, <b>Translations</b> and <b>Dilations</b> all <br>
							come in versor form.	
							</br></br></br></p>
</header>
<footer>
<a class="button" href="doc.html">Learn More</a>
</footer>
</article>
<article>
<div class="image round" id="3dcga">
</div>
<script>
							// Create a Clifford Algebra with 4,1 metric for 3D CGA.
							Algebra(4,1,()=>{

							// We start by defining a null basis, and upcasting for points
							  var ni = 1e4+1e5, no = .5e5-.5e4, nino = ni^no;
							  var up = (x)=> no + x + .5*x*x*ni;

							// Next we'll define some objects.
							  var p  = up(0),                          // point
							      S  = ()=>!(p-.5*ni),                 // main dual sphere around point (interactive)
							      S2 = !(up(-1.4e1)-0.125*ni),         // left dual sphere
							      C  = !(up(1.4e1)-.125*ni)&!(1e3),    // right circle
							      L  = up(.9e2)^up(.9e2-1e1)^ni,       // top line
							      P  = !(1e2-.9*ni),                   // bottom dual plane
							      P2 = !(1e1+1.7*ni);                   // right dual plane

							// The intersections of the big sphere with the other 4 objects.
							  var C1 = ()=>S&P, C2 = ()=>S&L, C3 = ()=>S&S2, C4 = ()=>S&C, C5 = ()=>C&P2;
							  
							// For line meet plane its a bit more involved.
							  var lp = up(nino<<(P2&L^no));

							// Graph the items. (hex numbers are html5 colors, two extra first bytes = alpha)
							  var con = document.getElementById('3dcga');
							  var can = con.appendChild(this.graph([ 
							      ()=>{
								p = up(Math.sin(performance.now()/1234)*1e2+1e0);  
							      },
							      0x00FF0000, p,              // point 
							      0xFF00FF,lp,               // line intersect plane
							      0x0000FF,C1,               // sphere meet plane
							      0x888800,C2,               // sphere meet line
							      0x0088FF,C3,               // sphere meet sphere
							      0x008800,C4,               // sphere meet circle
							      0x880000,C5,               // circle meet sphere
							      0,L,0,C,                         // line and circle
							      0xE0008800, P, P2,               // plane
							      0xE0FFFFFF, S, S2          // spheres
							  ],{lineWidth:6, spin:0.2,animate:false,scale:0.5,alpha:true,conformal:true,gl:true,grid:false}));
							  can.style.width='300px';
							  can.style.height='170px';
							  can.style.background='transparent';
							});
							</script>
<header>
<h3>$\mathbb R_{4,1}$ : 3D CGA</h3>
<p>
							In <b>3D CGA</b>, points <b>join</b> ($\wedge$) into pairs, lines,<br>
							circles, planes and spheres, which <b>meet</b> ($\vee$) in points,<br>
							pairs, circles and lines. <b>Rotations</b>, <b>Translations</b><br>
							and <b>Dilations</b> all come in versor form.	
							</br></br></br></p>
</header>
<footer>
<a class="button" href="doc.html">Learn More</a>
</footer>
</article>
</div>
</div>
</section>

    .on('exit', (x)=>{if(x.options)x.options.animate=false; console.log('canvas off '+x.parentElement.id); });

Title: Launch HN: Maritime Fusion (YC W25) – Fusion Reactors for Ships
URL: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=43185246
Article content:
<html lang="en" op="item"><head><meta content="origin" name="referrer"/><meta content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" name="viewport"/><link href="news.css?Y6kWEjCA9NYsuD0e1zNN" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
<link href="y18.svg" rel="icon"/>
<link href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=43185246" rel="canonical"> <title>Launch HN: Maritime Fusion (YC W25) – Fusion Reactors for Ships | Hacker News</title></link></head><body><center><table bgcolor="#f6f6ef" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="hnmain" width="85%">
<tr><td bgcolor="#ff6600"><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="padding:2px" width="100%"><tr><td style="width:18px;padding-right:4px"><a href="https://news.ycombinator.com"><img height="18" src="y18.svg" style="border:1px white solid; display:block" width="18"/></a></td>
<td style="line-height:12pt; height:10px;"><span class="pagetop"><b class="hnname"><a href="news">Hacker News</a></b>
<a href="newest">new</a> | <a href="front">past</a> | <a href="newcomments">comments</a> | <a href="ask">ask</a> | <a href="show">show</a> | <a href="jobs">jobs</a> | <a href="submit" rel="nofollow">submit</a> </span></td><td style="text-align:right;padding-right:4px;"><span class="pagetop">
<a href="login?goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246">login</a>
</span></td>
</tr></table></td></tr>
<tr id="pagespace" style="height:10px" title="Launch HN: Maritime Fusion (YC W25) – Fusion Reactors for Ships"></tr><tr><td><table border="0" class="fatitem">
<tr class="athing submission" id="43185246">
<td align="right" class="title" valign="top"><span class="rank"></span></td> <td class="votelinks" valign="top"><center><a href="vote?id=43185246&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43185246"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="title"><span class="titleline"><a href="item?id=43185246">Launch HN: Maritime Fusion (YC W25) – Fusion Reactors for Ships</a></span></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"></td><td class="subtext"><span class="subline">
<span class="score" id="score_43185246">166 points</span> by <a class="hnuser" href="user?id=jtcohen">jtcohen</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T16:32:46 1740587566"><a href="item?id=43185246">13 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43185246"></span> | <a href="hide?id=43185246&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246">hide</a> | <a class="hnpast" href="https://hn.algolia.com/?query=Launch%20HN%3A%20Maritime%20Fusion%20%28YC%20W25%29%20%E2%80%93%20Fusion%20Reactors%20for%20Ships&amp;type=story&amp;dateRange=all&amp;sort=byDate&amp;storyText=false&amp;prefix&amp;page=0">past</a> | <a href="fave?id=43185246&amp;auth=32c1088e7b9c2b3cfc7e41f21647351d75b55758">favorite</a> | <a href="item?id=43185246">180 comments</a> </span>
</td></tr>
<tr><td style="height:2px"></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"></td><td><div class="toptext">Hey HN, we’re Justin and Jason, co-founders of Maritime Fusion (<a href="https://maritimefusion.com/">https://maritimefusion.com/</a>). We’re working on putting fusion reactors on ships—specifically, large container ships and defence applications. Should be easy!<p>Yes, we know: fusion has been the energy source of the future…and it always will be. But high-temperature superconductors (HTS) have changed the game for magnetic confinement, and we believe we’ll witness Q &gt; 1 within a few (say 3) years. That’s huge.<p>(Side note: Q is the ratio of input power divided by output power. Q&gt; 1 means the reactor is producing more power than it consumes, achieving ‘breakeven.’)<p>However, getting to breakeven is just the first daunting challenge. Making the first-of-a-kind (FOAK) reactors cost-competitive on the grid? That might be even harder than achieving breakeven.<p>That’s why we’re taking this soon-to-be breakthrough in fusion and applying it to the first market we believe makes sense: ships.<p>Instead of targeting 24/7 baseload grid electricity—where fusion has to compete with solar, wind, batteries, and natural gas—we’re focusing on large commercial shipping (&gt;10,000 TEU) and mobile military vessels to provide ship-to-shore power capability.<p>Why ships? They don’t have great alternatives—the shipping industry is desperate to decarbonize. Hydrogen and ammonia are being explored, but come with serious downsides: low energy density, flammability, leaks, and massive infrastructure challenges. Fusion will provide a high-energy-density, long-range solution without the same infrastructure challenges—once it works, of course!<p>One common question is, why not fission? Fission works technically, but not practically. Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) <i>could</i> power ships, but licensing fission reactors on land is already brutally hard and expensive—doing it for vessels moving between international ports with enriched uranium is nearly impossible. Public perception is another major barrier: if we’re deploying thousands of nuclear reactors globally, they need to be meltdown-proof. Fusion is the only way to guarantee that. Regulation also isn’t as bad. While fusion won’t be a walk in the park to license, the NRC has declared a distinct framework for it—more like particle accelerators and hospitals than nuclear power plants. That’s a game-changer.<p>Instead of a 500+ MW grid-scale reactor, our system is 25 MWe, designed for ship propulsion. Our tokamak is roughly JET-sized, but with HTS magnets (8-9T) and higher plasma current (~10MA). The first-wall power flux is down from multi-MW/m² to nearly 500 kW/m²—still tough, but not nightmare mode. The materials challenges associated with the first wall and nuclear activation of the structures is greatly reduced. Also, ships don’t require 90% uptime like grid power plants. Downtime for maintenance is part of normal operations, making this a far more forgiving early application of fusion, unlike the grid where every down hour is lost revenue.<p>Jason and I come from SpaceX and Tesla, where we solved hard engineering problems at scale. My background is nuclear engineering (NC State, BS) and plasma physics (Columbia University, MS). We’ve been busy during our time in YC making technical progress on our reactor design, and are in the process of assembling a team of engineers who can pull this off.<p>This is a ridiculously hard problem, of course. But we think it’s the right hard problem—one that’s actually solvable (and worth solving!) with today’s tech if applied correctly. Eventually the cheaper and more robust SOAK and NOAK (second-of-a-kind and nth-of-a-kind) reactors will arrive in the coming decades (2050-2060) and then we'll pivot to decarbonising the grid and saving the world (we'll need to change our name), but until then we'll be out in the ocean!<p>Would love to hear your thoughts—whether you’re deep into plasma physics and engineering, skeptical-but–curious, or convinced it will never work . Ask us anything!</p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></div></td></tr> <tr><td style="height:10px"></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"></td><td><form action="comment" method="post"><input name="parent" type="hidden" value="43185246"/><input name="goto" type="hidden" value="item?id=43185246"/><input name="hmac" type="hidden" value="a403b8cfa2c7a7942b2434f799ea19d445f68e14"/><textarea cols="80" name="text" rows="8" wrap="virtual"></textarea><br/><br/>
<input type="submit" value="add comment"/></form></td></tr> </table><br/><br/><table border="0" class="comment-tree">
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43188856"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43188856&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43188856"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=FiatLuxDave">FiatLuxDave</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T22:13:52 1740608032"><a href="item?id=43188856">8 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43188856"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186062">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43188856" n="9">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Greybeard former fusion founder here.  Wishing you guys all the luck in the world!  Email in profile in case you wish to chat.<p>For all the naysayers, as a fusion startup, targeting the marine market is a good move.  They aren't even the first fusion startup to do so; IIRC Rostoker's group got their first major funding from the NRL. The marine market pays a premium for not having to refuel, and historically emerging energy technologies have early commercialization in ships.  This was true for fission in the 50s and for photovoltaic solar in the 70s/80s.<p>Now, sure, they have to make power to be able to sell it.  But to build a reactor, you have to raise funds, and in order to raise funds you have to show that you can make money if you are successful at making power.  Explicitly aiming at a market that might actually pay for overpriced power shows their investors that there may be a valid business case.  That doesn't make fusion happen any easier, but you don't make any reactions without first building a reactor.<p>You know, I'm sure these guys could work somewhere getting paid to get more people to click on stuff.  Instead they are taking a risk to do something that might be important.  Make no mistake: fusion founder is a tough gig.  There is no established off-ramp, and many fusion founders find that it's a job that can easily eat your career. I hope their plan B is in order, as well as their prenups and/or wills.  They are going off to fight a dragon that's eaten a lot of other people's careers, relationships and sanity.<p>As an aside, it's nice to see someone working on a tokamak actually not being overly optimistic about wall heat flux. It's like somebody actually paid attention to Stacey or something ;)</p></p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43188856&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343188856" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190390"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">

<div class="commtext c00">Can you elaborate on the use of photovoltaics in shipping? After a few searches, I haven’t been able to find anything that suggests the marine industry was an important sector for its development.<p>Also, I feel extremely confident predicting that the commercial maritime industry will never ever pay a premium for a particular fuel source. There may eventually be some applications where fusion is most efficient, but fusion reactors aren’t going to make their debut in cargo ships.</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190390&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343190390" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190449"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="2"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="80"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190449&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43190449"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=defrost">defrost</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T01:55:32 1740621332"><a href="item?id=43190449">4 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43190449"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43188856">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190390">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43191543">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43190449" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">I suspect they're referring to the use of PV cells in lighthouses, Light-Buoys, Wireless Relay Stations, LORAN (pre GPS marine navigation) stations, etc.<p>Economics at the time restricted their limited use to mountainous areas, deserts,  isolated areas, remote island outcrops, etc.<p>I saw PV use in the 1970s in remote Austalian rail operations to power signal boxes and repeaters .. the higher costs offset the equally high costs of maintaining a fueled generator in a remote location.<p>Marine <i>shipping</i> wasn't, to the best of my recollection, directly using PV's shipboard as they already had massive engines driving propulsion and it was trivial to bled off a little torque for a electrical generator.</p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190449&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343190449" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43191543"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="2"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="80"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">

<div class="commtext c00">Sailboat owners were early adopters of photovoltaics in order to avoid having to run generators. Some newer merchant ships have installed photovoltaics to supply part of the hotel load and maybe save a tiny amount of fuel, but that's a newer development and probably more of a "greenwashing" thing.</div>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43189536"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="2"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="80"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43189536&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43189536"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=nradov">nradov</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T23:34:03 1740612843"><a href="item?id=43189536">6 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43189536"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43188856">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43189133">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186062">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43189536" n="3">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">There is at least the <i>possibility</i> that fusion power could eventually be viable for privately owned civilian merchant ships. Fission power is a non-starter in that market due to concerns (valid or not) over security, terrorism, proliferation, and meltdowns. Even if someone builds a new fission powered merchant ship it would be useless because many nations wouldn't allow it to enter their ports.<p>Military fission power plants were never optimized for cost. They have always been hand built in tiny numbers with a focus on safety, durability, and maximal output.</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43189536&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343189536" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<div class="commtext c00">My understanding is that the tritium is bred in the reactor and then consumed in the reaction.  But most designs do have some amount of radioactive waste, including structural parts and reactor walls that suffer huge amounts of neutron activation.</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43190310&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343190310" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43186062"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43186062&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43186062"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=uranium">uranium</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T17:45:49 1740591949"><a href="item?id=43186062">12 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43186062"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43188856">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43187438">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43186062" n="5">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">"Downtime for maintenance is part of normal operations, making this a far more forgiving early application of fusion, unlike the grid where every down hour is lost revenue."<p>Planned maintenance, sure, but unplanned maintenance means the same lost revenue, plus you're stuck floating in the middle of the pacific ocean, possibly in need of parts or debugging expertise that only exists half a planet away or, for that matter, food.  It's certainly a good idea to find a niche to make market entry easier, but I would guess that reliability requirements are actually higher for ships than for microgrids.  Find some isolated town or island running off flaky diesel generators on shipped-in fuel and negotiate a reasonable SLA.<p>This ignores, of course, the bigger problem: making fusion work at all at Q &gt; 1.  If it were me, I'd work on solving that before worrying too much about optimizing market entry.  So far every single fusion effort has failed to clear that hurdle, and any effort on the other parts is wasted if you can't actually make power.</p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43186062&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343186062" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<div class="commtext c00">The first ocean-going steamships still had sails - it took many years for steam power to fully displace sail. Presumably a new maritime power system, like fusion, would follow a similar pattern.<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steamboat#Sea-_and_Ocean-going" rel="nofollow">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steamboat#Sea-_and_Ocean-going</a></p></div>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43188586"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="3"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="120"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43188586&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43188586"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=usrusr">usrusr</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T21:45:33 1740606333"><a href="item?id=43188586">8 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43188586"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186062">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186802">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43191011">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43188586" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Let's be realistic, it would have a diesel engine as a plan B.<p>But if you like sails: my pet hypothetical technology is wind-driven hydrogen tankers (or tankers for some other e-fuel derived from hydrogen) that sail out empty, then cruise around wherever there is plenty of wind. They'd have a turbine/generator setup driven by the water passing by and use the energy harvested there for filling the tank. Cruise around as long as it takes to nearly fill the tank then return to port (and fill the rest on the way back). There's <i>a lot of</i> oceans where systems like that could cruise around on. (same concept could also be used for desalonation, there it would not only be about energy but also about avoiding local brine concentrations)</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43188586&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343188586" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43187438"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43187438&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43187438"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=jandrese">jandrese</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T19:51:14 1740599474"><a href="item?id=43187438">10 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43187438"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186062">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43185999">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43187438" n="5">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">I think your timeline is at best optimistic.  I would personally like to see fixed land based fusion power work before we start trying to build them into moving vessels.<p>Your claim that the shipping industry is "desperate to decarbonize" also needs a citation.  From what I've seen shippers top three concerns are "how to minimize costs", "how to reduce costs", and "how to save money".  Can you make this system cheaper to operate than heavy fuel oil?  If not it is unlikely to gain traction.</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43187438&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343187438" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>
<tr class="athing comtr" id="43190662"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43190662&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43190662"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">

Before worrying about reliability in a storm or miniaturizing (to the point of that being irrelevant). <tr class="athing comtr" id="43185999"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43185999&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43185999"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=gpm">gpm</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T17:39:30 1740591570"><a href="item?id=43185999">12 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43185999"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43187438">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186391">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43185999" n="2">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">So your approach to fusion is "the same CFS but stay at roughly the size of the SPARC prototype instead of scaling up"?<p>When you say "Q &gt; 1 within a few (say 3) years" are you talking about your own reactors, or others? For that matter, are you trying to partner with CFS and license their technology or are you intending on starting "from scratch" (from whatever is publicly available)?<p>If that timeline is for fusion in general, what do you think your timeline looks like? Assuming adequate access to funding how soon can you build a Q&gt;1 reactor? How soon after that can you actually go to market and sell a reactor?<p>---<p>On an unrelated note, I'm curious what you think of the current approaches to commercial fusion being attempted. Are Tokamaks the only game in town in your mind? Or do the various other approaches also being tried out right now have a good shot (MIF/Zpinches/etc)? Any particular approaches you think are particularly likely to succeed.<p>This being ycombinator and a startup I'm obligated to say that I don't ask this question because I think it impacts your commercial viability much, the greatest risks in fusion definitely aren't the competitors. I ask it just because I'm curious what people willing to start a fusion company think of the competitors.<p>---<p>Ships make a ton of sense to me as an early market. An 11 figure market (according to my own napkin calculations awhile back) where power is much more expensive than on land. At the same time it's never struck me that the hardest part of building a fusion company is finding a market.</p></p></p></p></p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43186137"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43186137&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43186137"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=jtcohen">jtcohen</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T17:52:11 1740592331"><a href="item?id=43186137">12 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43186137"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43185999">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186391">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43186137" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Our device is larger than SPARC (~3m major radius) and less power (100MW fusion), hence the confidence in being able to solve the steady-state (repeated inductive pulses) engineering challenges.<p>We won’t be the first to Q&gt;1, I’m super excited for SPARC to achieve that and will be prepared with champagne.<p>We’re targeting early 2030’s for our reactor, we’re going straight for the full thing no sub scale reactor in between (we do have a plan for milestone-ing it out in a meaningful way)<p>I’ve worked on a few alternative approaches earlier in my career (FRC at Princeton, dense plasma focus at LPP Fusion) … I think all fusion approaches are worth looking at, but I’m placing my chips on the tokamak. If I were to pick a runner up, the stellerator.</p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43186137&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343186137" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43186522"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43186522&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43186522"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=dust42">dust42</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T18:28:22 1740594502"><a href="item?id=43186522">11 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43186522"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186094">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190235">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43186522" n="5">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00"><i>Also, what's you intermediate plans between :<p>2025 -&gt; Post on HN<p>2028 -&gt; Q&gt;1 achieved (by you ? by someone else ?)</p></p></i><p>CFS plans Q&gt;1 for 2027 with a tokamak design. If they succeed then there will be plenty of VC for similar designs. I'd place my bets that CFS succeeds with Q&gt;1. And I think the real problem will be the energy flux and neutron handling and thus much more a material sciences problem than a plasma physics problem. Thus the idea to look for a niche that has lower power needs is a very clever one. My bet would be rather on Maritime Fusion than Helion. But nevertheless, CFS will be likely first at Q&gt;1 however there is always space for another competitor.</p></div>

</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186094">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186522">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186532">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43190235">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43186780" n="3">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Let's also be really explicit... CFS is targeting Q&gt;1 by 2027 for nuclear fusion via the SPARC reactor, but not Q&gt;1 for electrical generation. The latter is slated for sometime in the early 2030s via the subsequent ARC reactor.<p>All of this is driven by HTS. Fusion reactors (generically) scale to the inverse^4 of magnetic field strength.  HTS doubled the achievable magnetic field strength of electromagnets, which means that ITER-like performance can be achieved in university-scale reactors at comercially-viable, lower costs.<p>Dr. Dennis Whyte (MIT Nuclear Eng Prof) gave a great seminar at Berkeley that covered some technical nuances.  It's mandatory watching if you want to geek out and understand the fusion hype: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rY6U4wB-oYM" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rY6U4wB-oYM</a></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43186780&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343186780" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<div class="commtext c00">“Obsolete” probably isn’t the right word but they’re continuing as usual on ITER.. they’re aiming for 5.5T compared to &gt;9T field strength on ARC.  There’s still a ton of science to be learned, so it makes sense to keep pushing ahead but it’s clear any eventual commercial design will use HTS magnets instead of the NbSn ones in ITER.</div>

<div class="commtext c00">This one I presume:<p>----------------------------------------------------------------<p>Dear battery technology claimant,<p>Thank you for your submission of proposed new revolutionary battery technology. Your new technology claims to be superior to existing lithium-ion technology and is just around the corner from taking over the world. Unfortunately your technology will likely fail, because:<p>[ ] it is impractical to manufacture at scale.<p>[ ] it will be too expensive for users.<p>[ ] it suffers from too few recharge cycles.<p>[ ] it is incapable of delivering current at sufficient levels.<p>[ ] it lacks thermal stability at low or high temperatures.<p>[ ] it lacks the energy density to make it sufficiently portable.<p>[ ] it has too short of a lifetime.<p>[ ] its charge rate is too slow.<p>[ ] its materials are too toxic.<p>[ ] it is too likely to catch fire or explode.<p>[ ] it is too minimal of a step forward for anybody to care.<p>[ ] this was already done 20 years ago and didn't work then.<p>[ ] by this time it ships li-ion advances will match it.<p>[ ] your claims are lies</p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></div>

<center><a href="vote?id=43187006&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43187006"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=d_silin">d_silin</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T19:10:24 1740597024"><a href="item?id=43187006">11 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43187006"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186094">root</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186582">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186838">prev</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186830">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43187006" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">And one for fusion<p>----------------------------------<p>Dear Nuclear Fusion Power Claimant<p>Thank you for your submission of proposed new revolutionary nuclear fusion power technology. Your new technology claims to solve humanity's energy problems, produce unlimited clean energy, and is just months away from commercialization. Unfortunately, your technology will likely fail, because:<p>[ ] it requires materials that cannot be produced at any scale.<p>[ ] its energy gain (Q factor) is still substantially less than 1.<p>[ ] its plasma instabilities modes are completely unknown.<p>[ ] its plasma modeling behavior relies exclusively on numerical simulations.<p>[ ] it cannot sustain required plasma confinement criteria<p>[ ] it cannot handle the neutron flux without rapid degradation of components.<p>[ ] it requires magnetic fields stronger than currently achievable<p>[ ] it consumes more energy in cooling systems than it produces.<p>[ ] your claimed breakthrough violates fundamental physics.<p>[ ] the same approach was tried in the 1960s, 1970s, 1980s, 1990s and abandoned each time for good reason<p>[ ] by the time it ships, renewable energy plus storage will be far cheaper.<p>[ ] your timeline has been "5 years away" for the past 50 years.<p>[ ] your claims are lies.<p>Sincerely,
The Energy Research Community</p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43187006&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343187006" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

<div class="commtext c00">How much design on an actual reactor can you do already if the whole technology isn't even demonstrated yet? How many changes are you prepared to do based on the results of the current scientific reactors?</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43185447&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343185447" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<div class="commtext c00">We can get pretty far along! From magnetic system design, vacuum vessel, RF heating system, cryogenic system, tritium fueling, etc we can start making a ton of progress today. The main things we still need to learn that can influence the design is advanced divertor scenarios and what are best material choices for plasma facing components (PFC's).</div>

<div class="commtext c00">Thank you for putting it this way.<p>I watched people scam VCs with drone tech, and Theranos, and other things.<p>Can people please do any amount of critical thinking around this sort of stuff? It steals funding from serious efforts and pollutes the pool.<p>What is special in this approach compared to literal decades in the field?<p>What is special about these young dudes compared to better-funded ventures that haven't pulled it off yet and who have been working on it longer?<p>What is the difference between "yeah we can do design work look at all this stuff (that's the easy 60-80% of the problem space)" versus "we can actually solve the remaining work that's got everybody so screwed up"?<p>This feels like a scam y'all, knowingly or not.</p></p></p></p></p></p></div>

<div class="commtext c00">I'm just going to put this here. Someone please make this a reality.<p>### *"Tokamak Sailor"*  
<i>(To the tune of "Drunken Sailor")</i><p>*(Verse 1)*  
What shall we do with a tokamak sailor?  
What shall we do with a tokamak sailor?  
What shall we do with a tokamak sailor?  
Early in the mornin'!<p>*(Chorus)*  
*Ho, ho! Fire up the plasma!*  
*Ho, ho! Fire up the plasma!*  
*Ho, ho! Fire up the plasma!*  
*Fusion in the mornin'!*<p>*(Verse 2)*  
Raise the coils and heat up the torus!  
Raise the coils and heat up the torus!  
Raise the coils and heat up the torus!  
Early in the mornin'!<p><i>(Chorus repeats)</i><p>*(Verse 3)*  
Confine the plasma, don't let it scatter!  
Confine the plasma, don't let it scatter!  
Confine the plasma, don’t let it scatter!  
Early in the mornin'!<p><i>(Chorus repeats)</i><p>*(Verse 4)*  
Sail with the power of fusion glory!  
Sail with the power of fusion glory!  
Sail with the power of fusion glory!  
Early in the mornin'!<p><i>(Final Chorus, extra loud!)</i>  
*Ho, ho! Fire up the plasma!*  
*Ho, ho! Fire up the plasma!*  
*Ho, ho! Fire up the plasma!*  
*Fusion in the mornin'!*<p>Now all aboard the reactor ship, lads! Keep that plasma hot, and may the tides be ever in our favor!</p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></p></div>

<div class="commtext c00">&gt; One common question is, why not fission? Fission works technically, but not practically. Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) could power ships, but licensing fission reactors on land is already brutally hard and expensive—doing it for vessels moving between international ports with enriched uranium is nearly impossible<p>What makes you think that licensing a fusion reactor will be easier? Safely handling tritium is fantastically more complicated that the fuel of a fission power plant.<p>Also, do you plan on breeding your fuel aboard the ship? If no, how do you plan to produce, store the tritium and refuel the ship? If yes, I'd like to know how you are planning to host the massive chemical plant to purify coolant, recycle unburt fuel, separate isotopes, detriatiate water and refuel that comes with your tokamak.</p></p></div>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43188432"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43188432&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43188432"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=jtcohen">jtcohen</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-26T21:27:17 1740605237"><a href="item?id=43188432">9 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43188432"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43188027">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43188832">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43188432" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>

<div class="commtext c00">Safely handling tritium is fantastically more complicated that the fuel of a fission power plant - I disagree with this, especially when considering the infinitely long HLW with fission fuel. Handling Tritium isn't easy but it's much more manageable.<p>Tritium breeding: we will have a FLiBe blanket and breed tritium, but we won't be processing and pulling out the Tritium on board, that will happen on land, so at port you drain the Tritiated FLiBe and replace it with Li-6 enriched FLiBe. There's a few companies working on the Tritium fuel cycle technology that are making great progress.</p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43188432&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343188432" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>

Is this still true? <div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43191781"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="1"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="40"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">
<center><a href="vote?id=43191781&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246" id="up_43191781"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center> </td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead">
<a class="hnuser" href="user?id=howenterprisey">howenterprisey</a> <span class="age" title="2025-02-27T06:07:03 1740636423"><a href="item?id=43191781">21 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_43191781"></span> <span class="navs">
             | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43187439">parent</a> | <a aria-hidden="true" class="clicky" href="#43186034">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" href="javascript:void(0)" id="43191781" n="1">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span> </span>
</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">Certainly the plasma could melt the wall if it were allowed to touch it, but by shaping the magnetic fields that confine the plasma, the plasma can be made to stay away from the wall (not perfectly, but well enough). This is how many fusion experiments operate today. The walls are made of tungsten and other materials that can handle heat, so even if (when) the plasma hits the wall, the melting isn't too severe.<p>Some "plasma touches wall" events are more severe than others. Sometimes it's even intentional. A "limited" plasma deliberately touches a part of the wall called the "limiter", and the limiter is used to bound the shape of the plasma. (Contrast with a "diverted" plasma; search both terms for more details.) On the other hand, one type of event where it's very much unintentional is called a vertical displacement event, in which the plasma, well, vertically displaces itself until it hits a wall and melts it. These suck but are planned for and handled.<p>If you're counting neutrons in that "energy flux", they'll just go through the wall (mostly); this is how tokamaks are supposed to make electricity, ie the neutrons go through the wall and hit a "blanket" that's much better at absorbing neutrons, and the blanket will heat up and the heat will be converted to electricity.</p></p></div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43191781&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343191781" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>
</table></td></tr>

<tr class="athing comtr" id="43188270"><td><table border="0"> <tr> <td class="ind" indent="0"><img height="1" src="s.gif" width="0"/></td><td class="votelinks" valign="top">

<div class="commtext c00">Unlike what the nuclear Navy does today which is directly mechanically link the steam turbine to the propeller... we have the turbine spin a generator that creates a high voltage electric bus, which can than power a motor for propulsion. But you can 'easily' swap out the motor and tap off that HV bus for any other electrical load. Agree with all those other potential applications for mobile power at sea, there's a ton! Even disaster relief after hurricanes sort of thing, if the grid goes down we sail over and support.</div>
<div class="reply"> <p><font size="1">
<u><a href="reply?id=43186585&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D43185246%2343186585" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u>
</font>
</p></div></div></td></tr>

</span></div><br/><div class="comment">
<div class="commtext c00">The underlying technology does not exist in a production form, to the extent that it's not clear which basic reactor design option is going to be the future. So we can't know what the maintenance burden from a fisson rector is, much less one mounted on a train.  Don't plan on tearing down those overhead cables just yet.</div>
